---
title: 'Relational recovery in co-occurring conditions: a qualitative study of first-person
  experiences'
type: pub
encoding: UTF-8

---
<h1>Publikasjon</h1>
<article id="csl-bib-container-7XXBRZAW" class="csl-bib-container">
  <div class="csl-bib-body"> <div class="csl-entry">Brekke, E., Ness, O., &#38; Lien, L. (2020). <div id="csl-bib-meta-7XXBRZAW" class="csl-bib-meta">
  <article id="about-article-7XXBRZAW" class="about_pub-article">
    <h1>Om</h1>
    Brekke et al. gjennomførte ein studie for å forstå korleis personar med både mentale helseproblem og rusbrukserfaringar opplever tilfriskning i sine relasjonar. Dei intervjua åtte individ og fann at relasjonar kan både fremje og hemme tilfriskning. Studiet identifiserte fire nøkkelerfaringar: å prioritere sitt barn, å handtere einsemd og tidlegare smerte, å ofre for ein partnar, og å gjenoppbygge tillit og støtte. Desse funna understrekar at tilfriskning er djupt knytt til mellommenneskelege relasjonar. Å forstå desse dynamikkane kan bidra til å betre støtte for dei som står overfor desse utfordringane, og framhevar betydninga av sosiale forbindelsar i tilfriskningsprosessen. Denne forskinga gir verdifulle innsikter for alle involverte i mental helse og rusbrukstilfriskning.
  </article>
  <article id="keywords-article-7XXBRZAW" class="keywords-article">
    <h1>Emneord</h1>
    Relasjonell tilfriskning, Samtidige tilstandar, Mental helse, Rusbruk, Mellommenneskelege relasjonar
  </article>
  <article id="abstract-article-7XXBRZAW" class="abstract-article">
    <h1>Samandrag</h1>
    Purpose: The purpose of this study was to explore and describe first-person experiences of relational recovery in co-occurring mental health and substance use conditions. 
Design/methodology/approach: Within a phenomenological and collaborative approach, indepth individual interviews with eight persons with co-occurring conditions were analysed 
using systematic text condensation. 
Findings: Participants described interpersonal relationships as both supporting and hindering recovery in fundamental ways. Four categories of experiences of relational recovery were described: (1) Choosing one’s child; (2) Living with loneliness and a painful past; (3) Sacrificing everything for one’s partner; and (4) Regaining trust and support. 
Originality/value: This article provides an enhanced understanding of how interpersonal relationships may be experienced by persons who live with co-occurring conditions. The results generally support an understanding of recovery as a relational process.
  </article>
